title: Harness Anger and Frustration for Survival Tasks
brief: Redirect anger and frustration from survival setbacks into productive energy for problem-solving.
steps: Recognize that frustration is inevitable when survival plans encounter problems.
When anger builds, immediately identify the specific problem causing it.
Channel emotional intensity from anger into physical survival tasks like firewood gathering.
Take 10 minutes to think through solutions before acting on angry impulses.
Use frustration as motivation to try alternative approaches to failed plans.
Focus anger at the situation, not at yourself or team members.
Convert 'I quit' attitudes into 'what else can I try' problem-solving.
warnings: Anger encourages impulsive reactions and poorly thought-out decisions.
Uncontrolled frustration can lead to an 'I quit' attitude.
Misdirected anger wastes energy that should go toward survival tasks.
